dialogue.statement: Hello! What brings you in today?

I’m just struggling with starting community college and feeling like I’m missing out on the whole college experience. It’s tough seeing friends at universities having fun while I’m stuck worrying about credits and commuting.

It must feel really challenging to see your friends enjoying a different experience while you're focused on other responsibilities. Can you tell me more about what aspects of the college experience you're hoping to have?

client: You know, like the social stuff—meeting new people, going to parties, living in dorms, just having that freedom and fun. Plus, being part of clubs or activities on campus. It just feels like I’m missing out on all that while I'm at community college.

It sounds like you’re really yearning for that sense of connection and the excitement that comes with the traditional college experience. What have you been able to do, if anything, to try and create some of those experiences at your community college?
client(exploring): Honestly, not much yet. I'm kind of at a loss on how to start. The whole setup feels different from what I imagined college would be like, and I'm not sure where to begin.

statement.reasoning: The client has clearly expressed their concerns about missing the traditional college experience and their feelings of regret and frustration. The therapist has successfully built rapport, shown empathy, and elicited the essence of the client's story, including the context and emotions involved. Mutually agreed goals, such as finding ways to recreate aspects of the desired college experience at community college, seem to be forming.

dialogue.statement: It seems like there's a strong desire to create a fulfilling college experience, even if it looks different from what you initially imagined. What do you think would help you feel more connected or involved at your community college?

client(guiding): Maybe finding a club or group that interests me, or just trying to meet people in my classes. But it's kind of intimidating, and I'm not sure how to go about it without feeling awkward.
It's understandable to feel uncertain about taking those first steps. What qualities or interests do you have that might guide you to a club or group where you’d feel more at ease?
client(guiding): Well, I’m really into music and art, and I’ve always enjoyed creative writing too. If there are any clubs related to those things, I think I’d feel more comfortable starting there.

Music, art, and creative writing sound like wonderful avenues to explore for connection. How would it feel to take a small step, like looking into clubs or events related to those interests on campus this week?
client(guiding): It feels a bit nerve-wracking, but also kind of exciting. I think it could be a good way to meet people who share similar interests, so I’m willing to give it a shot.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed a willingness to take steps toward change, particularly joining clubs related to their interests. The client feels both nervous and excited, indicating motivation despite some ambivalence. This suggests a readiness to explore concrete change strategies and overcome barriers, aligning with the Choosing phase. The goals of the Guiding phase have been met, including exploring values and eliciting Change Talk.

dialogue.statement: Exploring music, art, and creative writing clubs sounds like a great starting point. How about setting a goal to find and attend one club meeting or event related to these interests this week? You might also plan to speak with at least one person there. What do you think could be a challenge, and how might you overcome it?

client(choosing): That sounds doable, and I think the biggest challenge would be feeling too shy to approach people. Maybe I can remind myself that everyone’s there because they have similar interests, which could make starting a conversation easier. Plus, I could prepare some questions or topics beforehand to feel more confident.

Planning ahead with questions or topics is a great strategy to boost your confidence. So, your goal is to attend a club meeting or event and engage in a conversation with at least one person. Would you like to think about how you can monitor your progress, or perhaps set a reminder to follow up?

client(choosing): Yeah, setting a reminder would probably help. I could jot down how it went afterward, like what went well and what I can improve for next time. It might help me track my progress and stay motivated to keep trying.

That sounds like a thoughtful plan. Setting reminders and reflecting on your experiences afterwards can really help track your progress and keep you inspired. How does it sound to schedule a specific time each week to review your reflections, maybe even jot down any new insights or goals you might have?
client(choosing): That sounds helpful, actually. I can pick a day each week to look back on what I've done and set some new goals. It might remind me of the little wins and keep me moving forward.

statement.reasoning: The client has a clear goal to attend a club meeting and engage with peers, a concrete plan to overcome shyness with prepared conversation topics, and a self-monitoring strategy through reflections. The client demonstrates commitment and readiness to take steps, with confidence in the plan. All Choosing phase goals are met, showing readiness to move forward.

dialogue.statement: Reflecting weekly on your experiences and setting new goals is a fantastic way to recognize your achievements and maintain your momentum. This week, focus on attending that club meeting or event, engaging in conversation, and capturing your thoughts afterward. Celebrate those small victories along the way. Remember, it's all about growth and making the most of your college experience. You’ve got a solid plan, and taking these steps shows your commitment to creating connections. Looking forward to hearing about your journey next time we meet. Keep going—you’re on the right path!
Thanks, I really appreciate your support. I'll definitely give it a try and see how it goes. Looking forward to our next session to share what happened!

statement.reasoning: The client has a clear plan to engage in campus clubs related to interests, with strategies to overcome challenges, and a weekly reflection schedule. The session achieved closure by summarizing goals and next steps, inviting closure.

concern:
title: afraid of no college experience at cc pls don’t hate
i start my freshmen year of community college this month and im looking forward to it but also not since i already know the bad that comes from it. for ex: 

•no social life 
•NO COLLEGE EXPERIENCE 
•possibility of having a full class with middle aged parents/ business workers that randomly wanted to be in school again
• watching all my friends and mutuals have fun at their university that i also wanna attend to etc.
•being stuck in my room doing nothing etc 

i personally want to go to community for just one year then transfer and i know it’s harder that way if you don’t get your full 60 credits and transfer as a junior but why would i want to waste all my time at cc and possibly only have 1.5 years to enjoy myself at a uni??? community isn’t best for me but im only doing it because my high school gpa would not have gotten me into a uni and i do regret it because i skipped a lot or had very very bad mental health days so now i have to deal with the consequences and so community is really my only route for right now. and it sucks knowing that I won’t have the experience i want I know you’re thinking “the experience isn’t the main important thing just transfer in 2 years it’s not big deal plUs yOuR SavIng moNey” yeah I’ve read other reddit threads of teens expressing their same feelings that i have and it’s a bunch of the middle aged adults saying the same thing. let’s be honest here im 18 and so are the other peers that feel this way that are around the ages of 17-23 ofc we want to live a little and are pissed about having to be at community while everyone else is having fun. also you may know this but for some people university is their only escape route from home/toxic homes/ or just tired of being in their city cause they’ve been their all they’re life. it’s hardening to see and also i don’t live close to my community at all so it’s gonna be HELL trying to get there and back, my parents don’t own a car and i don’t trust a uber either. i just know this is gonna be one hell of a first year. any advice on how to deal through this? how i can make friends easier? IF i do end up having to do 2 years how should i get through it? what did you do?
